description: From Middle English kide, from Old Norse kið (“young goat”), from Proto-Germanic *kidją, *kittīną (“goatling, kid”), perhaps from Proto-Indo-European *gʰaydn-, *ǵʰaydn- (“goat”) or Proto-Indo-European *gidʰ- (“kid, goatling, little goat”). Compare Swedish and Danish kid, German Kitz and Kitze, Albanian kedh and kec.
Sense of child since 1590s as cant, since 1840s in informal use.

examples: I went, indeed, intending to kill a kid out of my own flock; and bring it home and dress it; but as I was going I saw a she-goat lying down in the shade, and two young kids sitting by her.

entries.meaning: Of a female goat, the state of being pregnant: in kid.
(uncountable) The meat of a young goat.
(informal) A child (usually), teenager, or young adult; a juvenile.
examples: She's a kid. It's normal for her to have imaginary friends.

entries.meaning: (informal) A person whose childhood took place in a particular time period or area.
examples: Only '90s kids will remember this toy.
He's been living in Los Angeles for years now, but he's a Florida kid.

entries.meaning: (informal) One's son or daughter, regardless of age.
(in the vocative) Used as a form of address for a child, teenager or young adult.
examples: No, kid, you didn't do anything wrong; they did!

entries.meaning: (colloquial) An inexperienced person or one in a junior position.
examples: I remember as a kid lawyer working at IBM in the summer of 1983, when a large insurance company in Hartford, Connecticut, for the first time asked to buy 12000 IBM PCs in a single order.

entries.meaning: (dated) A deception; an act of kidding somebody.
(nautical) A small wooden mess tub in which sailors received their food.
examples: peaceable, well-disposed chaps as ever eat duff (dough) out of a kid

entries.meaning: (vulgar, slang, usually in the plural) semen, ejaculate.

verbs.description: kid (third-person singular simple present kids, present participle kidding, simple past and past participle kidded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To make a fool of (someone).
(transitive, colloquial) To make a joke with (someone).
(intransitive) Of a goat, to give birth.
A fagot; a bundle of heath and furze.
